--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> I think tha=
t the decision to understand and prioritize your 
> tests will make a bigge=
r impact than the method you use to do 
> so.  

Yes, that's right for sure=
. 

> Myself, I like to gather tests into Java-level suite 
> classes, beca=
use these can be reused in ant, Eclipse, maven, 

This is true; however, th=
e drawback with too many TestSuites 
is that you have to recompile any time=
 you touch a single line 
of code, vs. just having to modify an external XM=
L file.

> One advantage of ant is that you can fail fast, deciding that 
>=
 if suite A fails, don't even bother running suite B.  Also, 
> sometimes t=
he build system or political structure of a team can 
> make it easier to e=
dit XML files than Java, in which case the 
> ant file might make sense.

S=
ome details on the environment:

* Rather small project and team (3-4 activ=
e developers, 
including myself), 
* Rather vanilla J2EE web application (S=
truts-based web gui and 
Hibernate+RDBMS backend)
* Rather mature developme=
nt stage
* All main activities (development, deployment and testing) are 
p=
erformed entirely with the IDE (Eclipse)
* Currently lacking an automated t=
esting/build environment (i.e. 
everything is done manually)

could these b=
e of any help in making a decision (or in finding a 
tradeoff)...?

Thanks
=
